claim_cards.claim: Multiple frontier AI models independently converged on a shared claim: gravity can be reframed as gradient coherence rather than a fundamental force.
claim_cards.test_hook: Audit model-to-model proposals for shared primitives and independent emergence (no shared prompt lineage); score overlap on definitions + equations + predictions.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: multiple frontier AI models ... converged ... gravity is best understood as gradient coherence

claim_cards.claim: The framework proposes replacing the stress–energy tensor with a coherence tensor Φ built from an action-density field S(x) with a scale-dependent coupling λ(r).
claim_cards.test_hook: Given S(x) + λ(r), compute Φ and compare whether it reproduces known weak-field behavior and predicts saturation regimes near high density.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: Replace the stress-energy tensor with a coherence tensor Φμν built from a scalar action-density field S(x) and a scale-dependent coupling λ(r).

claim_cards.claim: Φμν is defined as a second-derivative tensor of S(x) with a subtractive trace term scaled by λ(r), positioning λ as a viscosity-like coupling.
claim_cards.test_hook: Implement Φμν from the given definition; check coordinate invariance and sensitivity to λ(r) choices across scales.

claim_cards.claim: A scalar invariant I is defined as ΦμνΦμν, intended to represent coherence intensity and to enable dimensionless regime comparisons.
claim_cards.test_hook: Compute I in toy fields and in any analog simulation; test whether I behaves as an intensity measure with meaningful saturation behavior.

claim_cards.claim: A dimensionless 'coherence pressure' is defined and claimed to plateau near unity (≈1 ± 0.02) in strong-gravity regimes, analogous to an attractor.
claim_cards.test_hook: In any analog model or simulation, compute Φpressure and test whether high-intensity regions converge to ~1 within stated tolerance.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: Φpressure ≡ |∂t S| / √I ... In strong gravity, Φpressure tends toward 1 ± 0.02

claim_cards.claim: Φ evolution is posed as a reaction–diffusion system with diffusion D(I) and a relaxation term toward a saturation intensity I*, plus leakage γ.
claim_cards.test_hook: Numerically solve the reaction–diffusion form for Φ with varying D(I); test whether it yields stable funnels and saturation plateaus.

claim_cards.claim: Diffusion is proposed to fall as intensity rises, making high-I regions stiff and producing a bottleneck near massive objects (a 'coherence funnel').
claim_cards.test_hook: Set D(I)=D0/I^α (or similar decreasing law) and test whether funnels emerge and whether gradients concentrate near the source.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: Choose D(I) = D0/I^α ... diffusion shuts down as I → I* ... gravity is the bottleneck effect

claim_cards.claim: An event horizon is reframed as a saturation boundary where I(r)=I* and ∂r I=0; inside, coherence becomes phase-locked rather than causally discontinuous.
claim_cards.test_hook: In simulation, identify radii where I hits I* and gradient vanishes; test for phase-lock / suppressed diffusion behavior inside.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: At r = r_h, I(r_h) = I* and ∂r I|r_h = 0 ... event horizon is a saturation boundary

claim_cards.claim: A conservation law is asserted: ∇μ Φμν = 0, interpreted as conservation of alignment work rather than energy–momentum.
claim_cards.test_hook: Given Φ from S(x), evaluate ∇μ Φμν numerically; treat deviation as model error and test whether corrected λ(r) reduces divergence.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: ∇μ Φμν = 0 ... conservation of alignment work rather than just energy-momentum

claim_cards.claim: Curvature is framed as the observable silhouette of a conserved coherence field, not as a pre-given fabric acted on by mass.
claim_cards.test_hook: Map how curvature-like observables would be reconstructed from Φ/I fields; compare predictions against standard curvature-only descriptions.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: Curvature becomes the observable silhouette of a conserved coherence field.

claim_cards.claim: A cross-domain mapping is proposed: coherence funnels and saturation horizons (I=I*) correspond to market/institution saturation (J=J*), beyond which extraction destabilizes alignment.
claim_cards.test_hook: Define an empirical proxy J(t) for institutional/market alignment intensity; test for saturation plateaus and instability beyond them.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: Economic Horizon: At some point, J reaches J* and diffusion shuts down ... further extraction destabilizes the system.

claim_cards.claim: Scientific stovepipes are modeled as near-zero diffusion between fields; progress stalls when contextual filters lock diffusion at D≈0.
claim_cards.test_hook: Operationalize 'diffusion' as cross-field concept transfer rate; measure before/after interventions designed to raise diffusion.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: stovepipes ... behave as if diffusion between fields is zero ... local coherence cannot propagate

claim_cards.claim: The paper flags testable hooks: anomalies in high-Φ regimes (frame-dragging-like effects) and analog simulation via reaction–diffusion systems.
claim_cards.test_hook: Propose one analog reaction–diffusion experiment and one astrophysical high-Φ observational signature; pre-register expected directionality.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: Suggested testable predictions, such as frame-dragging-like anomalies in high-Φ regimes and analog simulation in reaction–diffusion systems.

claim_cards.claim: Gravity is framed as the cost of coherence maintaining itself; it presents as attraction plus waste-heat.
claim_cards.test_hook: In an analogue or simulation setting, define an alignment-maintenance proxy and a dissipation proxy; test whether increased 'attraction-like' effects co-vary with dissipation as predicted.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: Gravity is the cost of coherence maintaining itself. It appears as attraction plus waste-heat.

claim_cards.claim: Dark matter, dark energy, and black holes are asserted to be manifestations of the same conserved coherence field, misread through the wrong metric.
claim_cards.test_hook: Treat as a unification claim: derive at least one shared invariant or shared saturation behavior that must hold across the three regimes; test against baseline models that treat them separately.
claim_cards.evidence_excerpt: These are not separate problems... manifestations of the same conserved coherence field
